<article id="post-653" class="hitmag-page post-653 page type-page status-publish hentry">

	
	<header class="entry-header">
		<h1 class="entry-title">Domain-specific Hardware Accelerators</h1>	</header><!-- .entry-header -->

	
	
	<div class="entry-content">
		<div id="pl-653"  class="panel-layout" ><div id="pg-653-0"  class="panel-grid panel-no-style" ><div id="pgc-653-0-0"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-653-0-0-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-image panel-first-child panel-last-child" data-index="0" ><div class="so-widget-sow-image so-widget-sow-image-default-d6014b76747a">

<div class="sow-image-container">
	<img src="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/quantum-computing-1-1.jpg" width="696" height="500" srcset="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/quantum-computing-1-1.jpg 696w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/quantum-computing-1-1-300x216.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 696px) 100vw, 696px" title="quantum-computing-" alt="" 		class="so-widget-image"/>
</div>

</div></div></div><div id="pgc-653-0-1"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-653-0-1-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-editor panel-first-child" data-index="1" ><div class="so-widget-sow-editor so-widget-sow-editor-base"><h3 class="widget-title">Programmable Accelerators for Lattice-based Public Key Protocols</h3>
<div class="siteorigin-widget-tinymce textwidget">
	<p>Post Quantum Lattice-Based Cryptography (LBC) schemes are increasingly gaining attention in traditional and emerging security problems, such as encryption, digital signature, key exchange, homomorphic encryption etc, to address security needs of both short and long-lived devices — due to their foundational properties and ease of implementation. However, LBC schemes induce higher computational demand compared to classic schemes (e.g., DSA, ECDSA) for equivalent security guarantees, making domain-specific acceleration a viable option for improving security and favor early adoption of LBC schemes by the semiconductor industry.</p>
</div>
</div></div><div id="panel-653-0-1-1" class="so-panel widget widget_siteorigin-panels-builder panel-last-child" data-index="2" ><div class="project-bottom panel-widget-style panel-widget-style-for-653-0-1-1" ><div id="pl-w5ba15aa7c169b"  class="panel-layout" ><div id="pg-w5ba15aa7c169b-0"  class="panel-grid panel-no-style" ><div id="pgc-w5ba15aa7c169b-0-0"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-w5ba15aa7c169b-0-0-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-editor panel-first-child panel-last-child" data-index="0" ><div class="so-widget-sow-editor so-widget-sow-editor-base">
<div class="siteorigin-widget-tinymce textwidget">
	<p>Sponsor:</p>
<div id='gallery-2' class='gallery galleryid-653 gallery-columns-5 gallery-size-thumbnail'><figure class='gallery-item'>
			<div class='gallery-icon landscape'>

			</div>

				UC Irvine
				</figcaption></figure>

</div>
</div></div></div><div id="pgc-w5ba15aa7c169b-0-1"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-w5ba15aa7c169b-0-1-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-editor panel-first-child panel-last-child" data-index="1" ><div class="so-widget-sow-editor so-widget-sow-editor-base">
<div class="siteorigin-widget-tinymce textwidget">
	<p>People:</p>
<div id='gallery-4' class='gallery galleryid-653 gallery-columns-5 gallery-size-thumbnail'><figure class='gallery-item'>
			<div class='gallery-icon landscape'>
				<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/hamidnejatollahi/" class="no-lightbox"><img width="150" height="150" src="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/02/Hamid-150x150.jpg" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" alt="" aria-describedby="gallery-4-160" srcset="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/02/Hamid-150x150.jpg 150w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/02/Hamid-300x300.jpg 300w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/02/Hamid-768x768.jpg 768w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/02/Hamid-1024x1024.jpg 1024w" sizes="(max-width: 150px) 100vw, 150px" /></a>
			</div>
				<figcaption class='wp-caption-text gallery-caption' id='gallery-4-160'>
				Hamid Nejatollahi
				</figcaption></figure><figure class='gallery-item'>
			<div class='gallery-icon landscape'>
				<a href="https://rocammarota.info/" class="no-lightbox"><img width="150" height="150" src="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/09/RC-150x150.jpg" class="attachment-thumbnail size-thumbnail" alt="" aria-describedby="gallery-4-771" srcset="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/09/RC-150x150.jpg 150w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/09/RC-300x300.jpg 300w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/09/RC-768x768.jpg 768w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/09/RC.jpg 797w" sizes="(max-width: 150px) 100vw, 150px" /></a>
			</div>
				<figcaption class='wp-caption-text gallery-caption' id='gallery-4-771'>
				Rosario Cammarota
				</figcaption></figure>
		</div>

</div>
</div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div id="pg-653-1"  class="panel-grid panel-no-style" ><div id="pgc-653-1-0"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-653-1-0-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-image panel-first-child panel-last-child" data-index="3" ><div class="so-widget-sow-image so-widget-sow-image-default-d6014b76747a">

<div class="sow-image-container">
	<img src="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/ML-resizeimage.jpg" width="620" height="465" srcset="https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/ML-resizeimage.jpg 620w, https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/uploads/2018/08/ML-resizeimage-300x225.jpg 300w" sizes="(max-width: 620px) 100vw, 620px" alt="" 		class="so-widget-image"/>
</div>

</div></div></div><div id="pgc-653-1-1"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-653-1-1-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-editor panel-first-child" data-index="4" ><div class="so-widget-sow-editor so-widget-sow-editor-base"><h3 class="widget-title">Scale Down Neural Network Models Considering HW Constraints</h3>
<div class="siteorigin-widget-tinymce textwidget">
	<p>Traditionally machine learning (ML) computations have been performed on resourceful servers due to the high computational demands of these ML techniques. However, when these ML techniques are deployed for emerging applications that are heavily resource-constrained (e.g., smartphones, mobile platforms, IoT devices), time-critical (e.g., self-driving cars), or in environments where cloud connectivity is not reliably available, there is a need to perform ML computation/acceleration on the device itself. Furthermore, consumers are increasingly concerned about the privacy of their data when stored on public clouds.  All of these concerns pose daunting challenges for ML formulations and on-device acceleration.  On one hand, due to the limited resources, on-device AI should scale-down the network models (e.g. changing the number of layers, neurons per layer, etc.).  On the other hand, on-device AI acceleration must simultaneously satisfy multiple constraints including power consumption, latency, privacy and accuracy of the prediction.</p>
</div>
</div></div><div id="panel-653-1-1-1" class="so-panel widget widget_siteorigin-panels-builder panel-last-child" data-index="5" ><div class="project-bottom panel-widget-style panel-widget-style-for-653-1-1-1" ><div id="pl-w5d11373ee5b45"  class="panel-layout" ><div id="pg-w5d11373ee5b45-0"  class="panel-grid panel-no-style" ><div id="pgc-w5d11373ee5b45-0-0"  class="panel-grid-cell" ><div id="panel-w5d11373ee5b45-0-0-0" class="so-panel widget widget_sow-editor panel-first-child panel-last-child" data-index="0" ><div class="so-widget-sow-editor so-widget-sow-editor-base">
<div class="siteorigin-widget-tinymce textwidget">
	<p>Sponsor:</p>

title = {Post-Quantum Lattice-Based Cryptography Implementations: A Survey},<br />
author = {Nejatollahi, Hamid and Dutt, Nikil and Ray, Sandip and Regazzoni, Francesco and Banerjee, Indranil and Cammarota, Rosario},<br />

journal = {ACM Computing Survey},<br />
volume = {51},<br />
number = {6},<br />
abstract = {The advent of quantum computing threatens to break many classical cryptographic schemes, leading to innovations in public key cryptography that focus on post-quantum cryptography primitives and protocols resistant to quantum computing threats. Lattice-based cryptography is a promising post-quantum cryptography family, both in terms of foundational properties as well as in its application to both traditional and emerging security problems such as encryption, digital signature, key exchange, and homomorphic encryption. While such techniques provide guarantees, in theory, their realization on contemporary computing platforms requires careful design choices and tradeoffs to manage both the diversity of computing platforms (e.g., high-performance to resource constrained), as well as the agility for deployment in the face of emerging and changing standards. In this work, we survey trends in lattice-based cryptographic schemes, some recent fundamental proposals for the use of lattices in computer security, challenges for their implementation in software and hardware, and emerging needs for their adoption. The survey means to be informative about the math to allow the reader to focus on the mechanics of the computation ultimately needed for mapping schemes on existing hardware or synthesizing part or all of a scheme on special-purpose hardware.},<br />
keywords = {},<br />
pubstate = {published},<br />
tppubtype = {article}<br />
}<br />
</div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1297','tp_bibtex')">Close</a></p></div><div class="tp_abstract" id="tp_abstract_1297" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_abstract_entry">The advent of quantum computing threatens to break many classical cryptographic schemes, leading to innovations in public key cryptography that focus on post-quantum cryptography primitives and protocols resistant to quantum computing threats. Lattice-based cryptography is a promising post-quantum cryptography family, both in terms of foundational properties as well as in its application to both traditional and emerging security problems such as encryption, digital signature, key exchange, and homomorphic encryption. While such techniques provide guarantees, in theory, their realization on contemporary computing platforms requires careful design choices and tradeoffs to manage both the diversity of computing platforms (e.g., high-performance to resource constrained), as well as the agility for deployment in the face of emerging and changing standards. In this work, we survey trends in lattice-based cryptographic schemes, some recent fundamental proposals for the use of lattices in computer security, challenges for their implementation in software and hardware, and emerging needs for their adoption. The survey means to be informative about the math to allow the reader to focus on the mechanics of the computation ultimately needed for mapping schemes on existing hardware or synthesizing part or all of a scheme on special-purpose hardware.</div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1297','tp_abstract')">Close</a></p></div><div class="tp_links" id="tp_links_1297" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_links_entry"><ul class="tp_pub_list"><li><a class="tp_pub_list" style="background-image: url(https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/plugins/teachpress/images/mimetypes/text-html.png)" href="https://dx.doi.org/10.1145/3292548" title="Follow DOI:10.1145/3292548" target="_blank">doi:10.1145/3292548</a></li></ul></div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1297','tp_links')">Close</a></p></div></td></tr><tr>

                        <h3 class="tp_h3" id="tp_h3_2018">2018</h3>
                    </td>
                </tr><tr class="tp_publication"><td class="tp_pub_info"><p class="tp_pub_author"> Nejatollahi, Hamid;  Dutt, Nikil;  Banerjee, Indranil;  Cammarota, Rosario</p><p class="tp_pub_title"><a class="tp_title_link" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1287','tp_links')" style="cursor:pointer;">Domain-specific Accelerators for Ideal Lattice-based Public Key Protocols</a> <span class="tp_pub_type misc">Miscellaneous</span> </p><p class="tp_pub_additional"><span class="tp_pub_additional_howpublished">Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2018/608, </span><span class="tp_pub_additional_year">2018</span><span class="tp_pub_additional_note">, (urlhttps://eprint.iacr.org/2018/608)</span>.</p><p class="tp_pub_tags"><span class="tp_abstract_link"><a id="tp_abstract_sh_1287" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1287','tp_abstract')" title="Show abstract" style="cursor:pointer;">Abstract</a></span> | <span class="tp_resource_link"><a id="tp_links_sh_1287" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1287','tp_links')" title="Show links and resources" style="cursor:pointer;">Links</a></span> | <span class="tp_bibtex_link"><a id="tp_bibtex_sh_1287" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1287','tp_bibtex')" title="Show BibTeX entry" style="cursor:pointer;">BibTeX</a></span></p><div class="tp_bibtex" id="tp_bibtex_1287" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_bibtex_entry">@misc{cryptoeprint:2018:608,<br />
title = {Domain-specific Accelerators for Ideal Lattice-based Public Key Protocols},<br />
author = {Hamid Nejatollahi and Nikil Dutt and Indranil Banerjee and Rosario Cammarota},<br />
url = {https://eprint.iacr.org/2018/608.pdf},<br />
year  = {2018},<br />
date = {2018-01-01},<br />
abstract = {Post Quantum Lattice-Based Cryptography (LBC) schemes are increasingly gaining attention in traditional and emerging security problems, such as encryption, digital signature, key exchange, homomorphic encryption etc, to address security needs of both short and long-lived devices — due to their foundational properties and ease of implementation. However, LBC schemes induce higher computational demand compared to classic schemes (e.g., DSA, ECDSA) for equivalent security guarantees, making domain-specific acceleration a viable option for improving security and favor early adoption of LBC schemes by the semiconductor industry. In this paper, we present a workflow to explore the design space of domain-specific accelerators for LBC schemes, to target a diverse set of host devices, from resource-constrained IoT devices to high-performance computing platforms. We present design exploration results on workloads executing NewHope and BLISSB-I schemes accelerated by our domain-specific accelerators, with respect to a baseline without acceleration. We show that achieved performance with acceleration makes the execution of NewHope and BLISSB-I comparable to classic key exchange and digital signature schemes while retaining some form of general purpose programmability. In addition to 44% and 67% improvement in energy-delay product (EDP), we enhance performance (cycles) of the sign and verify steps in BLISSB-I schemes by 24% and 47%, respectively. Performance (EDP) improvement of server and client side of the NewHope key exchange is improved by 37% and 33% (52% and 48%), demonstrating the utility of the design space exploration framework.<br />
<br />
},<br />
howpublished = {Cryptology ePrint Archive, Report 2018/608},<br />
note = {urlhttps://eprint.iacr.org/2018/608},<br />
keywords = {},<br />
pubstate = {published},<br />
tppubtype = {misc}<br />
}<br />
</div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1287','tp_bibtex')">Close</a></p></div><div class="tp_abstract" id="tp_abstract_1287" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_abstract_entry">Post Quantum Lattice-Based Cryptography (LBC) schemes are increasingly gaining attention in traditional and emerging security problems, such as encryption, digital signature, key exchange, homomorphic encryption etc, to address security needs of both short and long-lived devices — due to their foundational properties and ease of implementation. However, LBC schemes induce higher computational demand compared to classic schemes (e.g., DSA, ECDSA) for equivalent security guarantees, making domain-specific acceleration a viable option for improving security and favor early adoption of LBC schemes by the semiconductor industry. In this paper, we present a workflow to explore the design space of domain-specific accelerators for LBC schemes, to target a diverse set of host devices, from resource-constrained IoT devices to high-performance computing platforms. We present design exploration results on workloads executing NewHope and BLISSB-I schemes accelerated by our domain-specific accelerators, with respect to a baseline without acceleration. We show that achieved performance with acceleration makes the execution of NewHope and BLISSB-I comparable to classic key exchange and digital signature schemes while retaining some form of general purpose programmability. In addition to 44% and 67% improvement in energy-delay product (EDP), we enhance performance (cycles) of the sign and verify steps in BLISSB-I schemes by 24% and 47%, respectively. Performance (EDP) improvement of server and client side of the NewHope key exchange is improved by 37% and 33% (52% and 48%), demonstrating the utility of the design space exploration framework.<br />
<br />

 Dutt, Nikil;  Ray, Sandip;  Regazzoni, Francesco;  Banerjee, Indranil;  Cammarota, Rosario</p><p class="tp_pub_title"><a class="tp_title_link" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_links')" style="cursor:pointer;">Software and Hardware Implementation of Lattice-Cased Cryptography Schemes</a> <span class="tp_pub_type techreport">Technical Report</span> </p><p class="tp_pub_additional"><span class="tp_pub_additional_institution">University of California Irvine, </span><span class="tp_pub_additional_number">(CECS TR 17-04), </span><span class="tp_pub_additional_year">2017</span>.</p><p class="tp_pub_tags"><span class="tp_abstract_link"><a id="tp_abstract_sh_1288" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_abstract')" title="Show abstract" style="cursor:pointer;">Abstract</a></span> | <span class="tp_resource_link"><a id="tp_links_sh_1288" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_links')" title="Show links and resources" style="cursor:pointer;">Links</a></span> | <span class="tp_bibtex_link"><a id="tp_bibtex_sh_1288" class="tp_show" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_bibtex')" title="Show BibTeX entry" style="cursor:pointer;">BibTeX</a></span></p><div class="tp_bibtex" id="tp_bibtex_1288" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_bibtex_entry">@techreport{2017-Hamid-TR_Survey,<br />
title = {Software and Hardware Implementation of Lattice-Cased Cryptography Schemes},<br />
author = {Hamid Nejatollahi and Nikil Dutt and Sandip Ray and Francesco Regazzoni and Indranil Banerjee and Rosario Cammarota},<br />
url = {https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320963262_Software_and_Hardware_Implementation_of_Lattice-Cased_Cryptography_Schemes<br />
http://www.cecs.uci.edu/files/2018/06/2017-tr-1.pdf<br />
<br />
},<br />
year  = {2017},<br />
date = {2017-01-01},<br />
journal = {University of California Irvine, CECS TR 17-04},<br />
number = {CECS TR 17-04},<br />
institution = {University of California Irvine,},<br />
abstract = {Advances in computing steadily erode computer security at its foundation, and call for fundamental innovations to strengthen current practices in computer security, specifically in applied cryptography, from theory to standardization to actual implementations. At the same time, the emergence of new computing paradigms, such as cloud computing, software defined networks and Internet of Everything, demands devices to adopt an increasing number of security standards - with a diverse set of cryptographic primitives. This in turn calls for innovations in security beyond the foundational aspects, down to the actual design and deployment of such primitives and protocols while satisfying conflicting design constraints such as latency, compactness, and energy efficiency. The advent of Quantum computing threatens to break many classical cryptographic schemes, leading to innovations in public key cryptography that focus on post-quantum cryptography primitives and their protocols that are resistant to quantum computing threats. In particular, lattice-based cryptography is a promising post-quantum cryptography family, both in terms of foundational properties, as well as its application to both traditional and emerging security problems such as encryption (asymmetric, but also symmetric), digital signature, key exchange, homomorphic encryption etc. While such techniques provide guarantees in theory, their realization on contemporary computing platforms requires careful design choices and tradeoffs to manage both the diversity of computing platforms (e.g., high-performance to resource constrained), as well as agility for deployment in the face of emerging and changing standards. In this work we survey trends in lattice-based cryptographic schemes, some fundamental recent proposals for the use of lattices in computer security, challenges for their implementation in software and hardware, and emerging needs for their adoption.},<br />
keywords = {},<br />
pubstate = {published},<br />
tppubtype = {techreport}<br />
}<br />
</div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_bibtex')">Close</a></p></div><div class="tp_abstract" id="tp_abstract_1288" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_abstract_entry">Advances in computing steadily erode computer security at its foundation, and call for fundamental innovations to strengthen current practices in computer security, specifically in applied cryptography, from theory to standardization to actual implementations. At the same time, the emergence of new computing paradigms, such as cloud computing, software defined networks and Internet of Everything, demands devices to adopt an increasing number of security standards - with a diverse set of cryptographic primitives. This in turn calls for innovations in security beyond the foundational aspects, down to the actual design and deployment of such primitives and protocols while satisfying conflicting design constraints such as latency, compactness, and energy efficiency. The advent of Quantum computing threatens to break many classical cryptographic schemes, leading to innovations in public key cryptography that focus on post-quantum cryptography primitives and their protocols that are resistant to quantum computing threats. In particular, lattice-based cryptography is a promising post-quantum cryptography family, both in terms of foundational properties, as well as its application to both traditional and emerging security problems such as encryption (asymmetric, but also symmetric), digital signature, key exchange, homomorphic encryption etc. While such techniques provide guarantees in theory, their realization on contemporary computing platforms requires careful design choices and tradeoffs to manage both the diversity of computing platforms (e.g., high-performance to resource constrained), as well as agility for deployment in the face of emerging and changing standards. In this work we survey trends in lattice-based cryptographic schemes, some fundamental recent proposals for the use of lattices in computer security, challenges for their implementation in software and hardware, and emerging needs for their adoption.</div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_abstract')">Close</a></p></div><div class="tp_links" id="tp_links_1288" style="display:none;"><div class="tp_links_entry"><ul class="tp_pub_list"><li><a class="tp_pub_list" style="background-image: url(https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/plugins/teachpress/images/mimetypes/text-html.png)" href="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320963262_Software_and_Hardware_Implementation_of_Lattice-Cased_Cryptography_Schemes" title="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320963262_Software_and_Hardware_Impleme[...]" target="_blank">https://www.researchgate.net/publication/320963262_Software_and_Hardware_Impleme[...]</a></li><li><a class="tp_pub_list" style="background-image: url(https://duttgroup.ics.uci.edu/wp-content/drg/plugins/teachpress/images/mimetypes/application-pdf.png)" href="http://www.cecs.uci.edu/files/2018/06/2017-tr-1.pdf" title="http://www.cecs.uci.edu/files/2018/06/2017-tr-1.pdf" target="_blank">http://www.cecs.uci.edu/files/2018/06/2017-tr-1.pdf</a></li></ul></div><p class="tp_close_menu"><a class="tp_close" onclick="teachpress_pub_showhide('1288','tp_links')">Close</a></p></div></td></tr></table>
